name: Swedish Meatballs
headline: Swedish Meatballs
description: With more than 400 5-star reviews, Alton Brown's Swedish Meatballs recipe from Good Eats on Food Network, is a fan-favorite. This classic version uses a mix of ground beef and pork for the meatballs, paired with a quick pan gravy.
keywords: European Recipes,Swedish,Meatballs,Dairy Recipes,Pork,Beef,Appetizer,Sauteing Recipes,Recipes for a Crowd
recipeIngredient: A pinch plus 1 teaspoon kosher salt

recipeInstructions.text: Tear the bread into pieces and place in a small mixing bowl along with the milk. Set aside.
In a 12-inch straight sided saute pan over medium heat, melt 1 tablespoon of the butter. Add the onion and a pinch of salt and sweat until the onions are soft. Remove from the heat and set aside.

In the bowl of a stand mixer, combine the bread and milk mixture, ground chuck, pork, egg yolks, 1 teaspoon of kosher salt, black pepper, allspice, nutmeg, and onions. Beat on medium speed for 1 to 2 minutes.
Using a scale, weigh meatballs into 1-ounce portions and place on a sheet pan. Using your hands, shape the meatballs into rounds.

Heat the remaining butter in the saute pan over medium-low heat, or in an electric skillet set to 250 degrees F. Add the meatballs and saute until golden brown on all sides, about 7 to 10 minutes. Remove the meatballs to an ovenproof dish using a slotted spoon and place in the warmed oven.

Once all of the meatballs are cooked, decrease the heat to low and add the flour to the pan or skillet. Whisk until lightly browned, approximately 1 to 2 minutes. Gradually add the beef stock and whisk until sauce begins to thicken. Add the cream and continue to cook until the gravy reaches the desired consistency. Remove the meatballs from the oven, cover with the gravy and serve.

review.reviewBody: Meatballs came out so flavorful!! Was a hit with the family. Will definitely make this again ‚ù§Ô∏è
Came out really good. I used Mccormick seasoning and the recipe plus added cardamom and added cream of mushroom soup and mushrooms to the gravy. My husband had thirds. My go-to from now on.

My husband requested I make something that his mother used to make, Meatballs w Sauce on top of boiled potatoes. It is something I had never made and his mother is gone and I didn't have her recipe.

He loved this recipe. Raved about it all night and again this morning!

Thanks, Alton!

These are the best meatballs I‚Äôve ever made!!! I think the bread & milk were key! I added a little dill to the meat mixture, and made with Mafalde pasta (short curly shaped pasta.) I‚Äôve since modified this recipe to make it Multi Pot (Instant Pot/Ninja) and food processor friendly ü•∑

This recipe makes a LOT of meatballs, too many to fit in the multi pot at once so you would have to work in batches -I only cooked about 1/3 of them which was plenty for our family of three and froze the rest for future use.
*to freeze spread out onto parchment lined sheet pan for about an hour to flash freeze, then transfer to a freezer safe zip lock bag -this keeps them from sticking together and able to pull out smaller portions as desired.

I didn‚Äôt bother with clarifying the butter. I didn‚Äôt have a pound of ground pork so I minced a pound of pork chops in my food processor *pork loin would work too!

In a multi pot (IP/Ninja) using the sear-LOW function melt 1 Tbls of butter. Add onion and a pinch of salt saut√© until onions have softened, remove and place into food processor.

Add the bread & milk mixture, meats, egg yolks, 1tsp kosher salt, and seasonings to the processor bowl using dough blade, pulse just until well combined.

After you‚Äôve rolled out your meatballs set multi pot to sear-HIGH, add a little oil to coat bottom and allow it to heat up. Sear the meatballs until browned well on all sides, don‚Äôt overcrowd-work in batches if needed, then remove & set aside.

Turn multi pot function to sear-LOW. Add flour and cook for 1-2min while stirring with a whisk to break up clumps. Whisk in the beef broth. Add 8oz pasta or 1c rice of your choice.

Pressure cook on HIGH for 4 minutes, or until tender to your liking. Natural release if you want, I was impatient and used quick release. Sauce will thicken as it sits, you can stir in a little water or more broth to thin out if needed, but I was happy with the result!

Stir in cream & adjust S&P to taste. Return meatballs to coat & heat back through. Use keep warm setting on multi pot until ready to serve.

Basically a good recipe but needs tweaking....a larger portionof the roux (flur/butter) needed to thicken sauce properly.  Dijon and salt needed for sauce as well and I added a touch of nutmeg and allspice.  Meatballs are just right.
The meatballs has no flavor. The sauce was bland so I googled Ikeas recipe and added Dijon mustard to the sauce. Not a good recipe at all
I love this recipe! It‚Äôs simple and tastes delicious! I do however add a pack of McCormick Swedish meatball gravy to the gravy for extra flavor.
Tasted DELICIOUS
They were good but the flavor was somewhat lacking. The sauce also took on eternity to thicken up.

This is by far the best recipe for Swedish Meatballs I have ever tried!  My entire highly picky family ate it and had rave reviews for it.  It was completely consumed in just a few minutes!  It's now my go to Swedish Meatballs recipe!
I would not consider these ‚ÄúGood Eats‚Äù, more like Great Eats. IKEA would be jealous.¬†
This is the best Swedish meatballs recipe I've ever made. I did almost double the gravy ingredients!
I've found these don't have nearly enough spices in them, I triple the allspice, pepper, and nutmeg to make them more like the meatballs my beloved Swedish grandma made for us.¬†¬†
Alton you are my go to but I am of Swedish descent and these meatballs, though not bad, fall short of the mark unfortunately.
came out well , note let the meat ball alone when you start for 2 or 3 min before you move them around or they will stick to pan¬†
Delicious, creamy sauce. ¬†Meatballs reminded me of ones I had as a child :)

Yep. This works. Tastes like my 50/50 Norwegian/Swedish grandma made. Family loved it. ¬†(I did follow some reviewers suggestions and added 1/3t cardamom and slightly reduced the salt in meatballs and added a bit of dill, nutmeg, salt and pepper to gravy.) Oh, and pro tip (from a novice), apparently 2 left-over hotdog buns work just fine. :)¬†
Good
Very dry and bland. Should be creamier! Very disappointed

Terrific! I would say you don‚Äôt have to put the meatballs in the oven, just lightly brown, no need to cook through, then make the sauce and transfer back into the gravy and slow simmer for at least 1/2 hour! I used German wide egg noodles and put a little fresh dill in the sauce!
Loved it. Easy to follow and delicious

Very delicious and savory.  Easier to make than I thought it would be. I served them with mashed potatoes.  My family enjoyed it and then I brought the leftovers to my parents who also thought it was delicious.
Go to on a cold winters day. Easy and filling. Goes well over everything including just eating from a bowl no noodles. Yum.
My requested Swedish meatballs for his birthday dinner. This was delicious. We served them over egg noodles.

Just wow! I've only had Ikea's Swedish Meatballs and was going to buy a bunch for the freezer next time I drove by the local store. But it's about 45 minutes away, so decided to try Alton's recipe. Not the simplest or quickest recipe in the book, but incredibly good. I plan on making a double batch next time and freezing half of the raw meatballs. I might try the ground cardamon that another poster suggested, but a perfect recipe as is. I did skimp a little on the beef broth and raised the heat on the sauce to thicken. I served over egg noodles. Outstanding!
First time making meatballs. I was surprised how easy they are to make. This recipe is delicious. I used the recommended seasonings but you could certainly modify them to suit.

The first time I made them they were very good.¬† The second time I made them my very Swedish wife suggested I add some ground cardamom.¬† I add 1/2 tsp and it took these meatballs to whole other level.
Just like my moms
It took me longer than expected to prepare.  That didn't stop my family and I from enjoying the dish. Just the right amount of spicy. I'm gonna add this to my rotation.
Thank you Alton Brown.¬†
You know a recipe is impressive when the measurement is 1 ounce meatball and you think you can weigh most of the batch until the last few and realize I should have weighed all of them!

This is a great recipe, and I‚Äôve made it several times.  The first time I made the recipe exactly as written, and it was outstanding. I always like to make recipes how they‚Äôre written first and then add in variations afterward.  The second time I had a partial container of white mushrooms in my fridge that were not going to be used for another recipe, so I chopped them finely and saut√©ed them in the pan at the start of my gravy.  While it isn‚Äôt authentic, it did boost the umami factor, and it added a nice touch to my gravy.  I‚Äôve also had success forming the meatballs and cooking 3/4 of them in the oven, and then cooking the remaining 1/4 in the pan to create a fond for the gravy.  It cut my cooking time down considerably since I didn‚Äôt have to cook the meatballs in batches. I do suggest slightly undercooking your meatballs and then adding them to the gravy to finish cooking. It definitely boosts the flavor of the gravy.  I‚Äôve also grated the onion and then saut√©ed it prior to adding it to the meat.  If you don‚Äôt mind little chopped pieces of onion in your meatballs, by all means leave them chopped, but grating the onion gives you more of a uniform texture in the finished meatballs.  This recipe is worth all the time and effort.  This is always a member of the clean plate club.
I took a shortcut that worked very well. Roll the meatballs in flour, fry them in butter. Eliminates making a roux separately.¬†

Absolutely delicious!  Followed the recipe to a T.  Suggest bringing the sauce to a boil to ensure it thickens adequately, otherwise it might be too soupy.  The meatballs were tender and lightly spiced with the allspice and nutmeg.  The sauce provided a delicate balance coating the meatballs in a lovely glaze.  Definitely worth the effort for each extraordinary bite.
He‚Äôs a genius
Excellent
This is a brilliant recipe! So simple. I‚Äôd recommend egg noodles or rice. The gravy is scrumptious. You‚Äôll need extra S&P, to make it perfect. The leftovers are better yet.

Absolutely fantastic and easy to make. This is my go to recipe when I want that tasty Swedish meat ball dinner. Serve it with green beans and mashed potatoes with lingonberry jam. You‚Äôll be thinking about this dinner a month later it is so good!

I was afraid it was going to be bland as some reviewers complained about, but it was actually pretty tasty. The one problem I encountered was burnt little pieces of onions and meat floating in the gravy; could anyone advise on how to avoid that?

I tried this recipe tonight and it was FABULOUS!¬† The only different thing I did was to put the meatballs in the gravy on the stove and cooked them in the gravy for about 15-20 minutes.¬† We all loved it and decided it was a definite keeper.¬† Thank you Alton :-)
Has the subtle flavor and comforting warmth that I was craving. Made this for dinner 2 days before Thanksgiving. Served over homemade noodles. Tossed salad. Just wonderful.
This is my go-to recipe for Swedish Meatballs. The only suggestions is to double the gravy. OUTSTANDING!

Lauren Anne - Yes, I make this recipe by hand, old school. Everything cooked, chopped, in a bowl and get your hands in it.
I don‚Äôt always use bread, usually breadcrumbs - 1/2 cup milk to 1/4 cup breadcrumbs. You could use 12 grain bread but it will alter the taste somewhat because of the bread ingredients - which you may or may not like - and you will have to adjust the seasoning and for moisture content, which I frequently have to do anyway because I usually make these or Italian meatballs from ground turkey which is a blander meat and tends to have a higher water content.
I also double the gravy because it‚Äôs so good!
This is my go-to Swedish Meatballs recipe.

I just made this recipe for my family and everyone was licking their plate!!! I paired it with an orange cranberry sauce along with the gravy that this recipe calls for served on top of mash potatoes and it was AMAZING!

Gluten Free... Substituted gluten free bread crumbs for the bread, added an extra egg yolk to help hold the balls together and used gluten free flour (mostly rice flour and potato starch) for the roux. Came out great!

wow, this turned out really good. I grated onions in a food processor and skipped the step of "sweating" the onions. I didn't have heavy cream but used whole milk with a bit more butter. The meatballs were better than IKEA with the 50/50 beef/pork.¬†I suspect IKEA is mostly beef.¬†A touch too salty, so cut back on the 1 teaspoon to 3/4 or 1/2.¬† Next time I'll add a bit more all spice and nutmeg (personal preference). I was worried about the lack of spices in the recipe, but they taste good other than very slightly too much salt and light on all spice and nutmeg. The sauce smells and tastes really close to the IKEA sauce...actually better....very pleased with this one.¬†

These turned out nicely! Never made Swedish meatballs before. Moist with a delicious gravy. I thought the meatballs were a little bland at first. I added more salt and some soy sauce. Didn‚Äôt want to buy allspice just for this recipes but it really adds a distinctive flavor. After simmering in the gravy for a while I think these were delicious!
I built a proper roux to thicken the gravy but even then, wasn‚Äôt thick enough for my liking.
Overall this is a great and reliable recipe.
These were AB. SOL. UTLY. Wonderful. I did not adjust a thing with this recipe!! I have NOT used a recipe, or advise, of Alton's that was not good. I WILL use this recipe again!!!

Delicious meatballs. I wasn‚Äôt going to clarify the butter but changed my mind and I think it was worth it in the taste of the meatballs. Very nice recipe that I will make again. I miss Good Eats. The science behind cooking isn‚Äôt something anybody else covers and Alton is so entertaining even my husband enjoyed the show. Food Network, there has got to be a slot on your schedule for Good Eats II, surely?
I made these for dinner tonight! We love them! My husband ,26 yr.old daughter & I
Just love them! I‚Äôve made these several times, everyone always enjoys them. Yum!
Excellent. Made this dairy free with coconut shortening, coconut cream, and rice milk. Excellent result. Add a dash of baking soda to meatball mixture for jucier meatballs...

Absolutely fantastic as the recipe is written. I usually make things the first time and then take notes on how adjust seasoning for the next time but this needs nothing. I will double the gravy next time.¬†

I thought the meatballs were decent, the sauce flat & boring. Followed the recipe exactly. I would not make these again.  I‚Äôm being generous with 3 Stars...really more like 2.5 as far as I‚Äôm concerned.

I followed the recipe pretty much to the tee, except did not clarify the butter. This was an easy and delicious version of many recipes I've made for Swedish Meatballs. I did, however, miss the nice tang of sour cream and so I served this dish over buttered egg noodles, adding a small dollop of sour cream right on top of each serving. Loved it!
Very delicious! Moist! Best of all, it makes a great leftover meal!
These are fantastic AB!! Only thing I added to the sauce was garlic and parsley. As always it‚Äôs a keeper!!‚ù§Ô∏è

I thought I had finally perfected a recipe for the Swedish sauce (which I tweaked a few similar recipes of each other to my liking) until I tried this one. It is so delicious and much easier than the one I was using. So glad for this. Thank you Alton Brown, the family and I love it!

I made this recipe for our New Year‚Äôs Eve party. Except I used only venison. To offset the game flavor, I added some fresh garlic to the meat before I mixed it. Didnt have allspice so added cinnamon in its place. The outcome was the perfect savory finger food.¬†

The meatballs are moist and delicious. ¬†I have made them several times! ¬†That being said, the gravy is just disappointing. ¬†It needs more seasoning/herbs/spices. ¬†I give it 4 stars because the meatballs themselves are so good.

Just doubled this recipe for a Packer party, so delicious and the sauce is creamy and flavorful. I've placed in a slow cooker to keep warm and moist. Those caramelized onion and brown bits in the¬† fry pay have added so much favor. Cant wait to share and get further feedback.
A definite go-to recipe. Delicious and a great make ahead meal. ¬†I often double this recipe and freeze the meatballs (not sauce) for a future easy weekday meal.

Delicious, flavorful, and they stay moist just as a good Swedish meatball should.¬† I used a combination of 98% lean ground beef and veal instead of ground pork.¬† I also added a little extra nutmeg because I love the taste of it.¬† The recipe did teach me something totally new though.¬† I have never clarified butter before, and it makes such a difference in the browning of the meat and flour.¬† It was great to not have everything get too dark.¬† Loved it
Yum. I used ground elk and ground sausage. I added mushrooms to the gravy and it was wonderful served over meatballs and mashed potatoes.

My husband and I¬†really enjoyed this recipe.¬† Made 1/2 recipe since I had 3/4 lbs. equal amounts ground beef, ground pork and ground veal.¬† Followed the recipe to the T.¬† Meatballs were delicious.¬† Found the gravy to be a bit bland so added some Dijon mustard (as someone suggested) and a bit of freeze dried dill.¬† Served over buttered noodles.¬† Will definitely make again.¬† Thanks Alton.
Awesome! I served it over egg noodles and it was great. It took quite a while to thicken the gravy, but it did thicken. I liked weighing the meatballs and having consistently sized portions.
SO GOOD! Not hard at all, and quick clean up. Served over egg noodles!
Made these exactly according to the recipe and they were perfect. For those of you who alter the recipe, you really should not be leaving a review.¬†

The meatballs are good. I used spicy Italian pork and it was delicious. The gravy, however, was not good (one of the worst I've tasted, actually). I had to work and work it to get it to taste good. That's what pushed this down to a 3-star meal.

Made this for the first time a couple weeks ago and my brother in law has requested it again every night since. I served it with egg noodles and roasted asparagus and it made a very filling tasty meal that fed a filled 4 people.
Great taste. I miss that show, ¬†"Good Eats"!

I have made thesis many time. excellent recipe . I double it and freeze the meatballs separate from the gravy. I spit the gravy before I add the cream and add the cream to the thawed our gravy when I use the second batch.. ALSO I agree the gravy is a little bland. I add a little¬†Dijon mustard as well as salt, pepper, and a little onion powder.¬†

Why are you complicating things so much Alton? Seems like a lot of commercial and other... equipment... to make little meatballs. Stand mixer? Some strange pan none of us have... nitrile gloves and an ice cream scoop? Not sure if I'm to perform surgery or make little meatballs! This should've presented as a very straight forward dish to make.

Read more at: http://www.foodnetwork.com/recipes/alton-brown/swedish-meatballs-recipe.html?oc=linkback

If your sauce does not thicken to your liking, like mine did. ¬†Never fear, try a¬†Beurre Mani√©: A mixture of flour and softened butter, which, when whisked into sauces, acts as a thickener.
Delicious! ¬†Love you anywho, Alton!
¬†
Simple and Delicious. My family loves this recipe and it is asked to be made often in our household.¬†

I have been searching for a Swedish meatball recipe for more than a year. I hated either the meatballs or the gravy.
Alton Brown's is the fourth or fifth version I tried - and it's the WINNER!
As I always do the first time, I made it exactly as written. I like the fact that the allspice and nutmeg are not overpowering - the amounts stated are fine as is, but of course you could increase or decrease to suit your own tastes.
The only thing I will change next time is to add more flour to make the gravy thicker. Otherwise, it's perfect as is!

These turned out exactly as I imagined swedish meatballs would taste. ¬†I COULD NOT STOP eating the sauce! ¬†My biggest mistake was not doubling the sauce as others suggested! ¬†I left all the fat & bits leftover from sweating the onions and browning the meatballs in the pan when I made the sauce - so delicious! ¬†In full disclosure, I used chicken stock and milk and didn't clarify my butter, but I did follow the procedure to the letter. SCORE!
Made this tonight, it was fantastic! Found some lingonberry jam at wegman's, and put the meatballs and sauce on top of egg noodles. A great "Swedish nite" dinner. Thanks

Oh yeah, and I messed this up so bad and it was still great.¬† See, if I followed it exactly I'm sure it would have been stupendous.¬† I bought ground turkey instead of pork, I used regular butter instead of clarified butter, and I completely forgot to add the egg yolks, AND used half and half instead of cream, and chicken stock instead of beef stock.¬† It was not my finest hour.¬† But it was still tasty and we all enjoyed it, except my super picky eater who thinks meatballs and gravy are gross.¬† My other kid, took the last 3 meatballs and made a¬† meatball sandwich for dessert - lol.¬† I made braised cabbage (from allrecipes) to go with this...perfect pairing.

Turned out pretty good. Although I made adjustments to our preference.
I used 2 lbs of organic ground beef. Finely diced carrots and saut√©ed along with the onions.
I used 2 whole eggs, didn't want to waste. Omit the nutmeg ( don't like ) added garlic powder instead,
Soaked wheat bread in 1% milk.
For gravy, I added more garlic powder, black pepper, white pepper, and salt. Used half and half.
Served with mushroom rice pilaf and saut√©ed spinach.
Delicious :)

video.name: Swedish Meatballs
video.description: Watch as Alton reinvents that '60s party classic, the Swedish meatball.
